componenttext:
Thank you, Pat, and good morning. Cablevision continued to perform well on the third quarter. The company's consolidated revenue increased 5.6% to $1.8 billion, fueled by steady growth in our Cable and Rainbow business. Meanwhile, we reported AOCF growth of 3.6%. However, after eliminating the favorable one-time adjustment that impacted our Cable business in the third quarter of last year, AOCF growth for this quarter would have been 8%.
Our results helped drive free cash flow of $225 million for the quarter, bringing the company's year-to-date total to $656 million, an increase of 10% compared to the prior-year period.
We are pleased with our ongoing ability to generate solid results, especially during a quarter that is traditionally seasonally light for our Cable business. The company also continued to experience positive momentum in the advertising market.
Cable and Rainbow delivered strong growth in the first and second quarter of this year. This trend repeated in the third quarter, and both businesses reported impressive double-digit increases in advertising revenue compared with the prior-year period. Cablevision also continued to execute on its plan to return value to shareholders with an active quarter in our stock repurchase program. In addition, the Board of Directors has once again approved a $0.125 per share dividend payable in December.
I would now like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Rutledge.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning. In the third quarter, the Telecom business delivered solid results, with revenue growth of 5.2% and AOCF growth of 7.8% after excluding last year's third quarter regulatory adjustment. The company gained 10,000 new high-s
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning. In the third quarter, the Telecom business delivered solid results, with revenue growth of 5.2% and AOCF growth of 7.8% after excluding last year's third quarter regulatory adjustment. The company gained 10,000 new high-speed data customers and 9,000 new voice customers in the quarter.
Basic Video subs declined by 25,000. Third quarter is always the weakest quarter for Cablevision. And while video did better this year than last year, it is negatively impacted by weakness in the housing sector.
The telco overbuild appears to have ceased from a construction standpoint in our footprint. We've seen very little new build activity the quarter. Presently, they have passed a little less than 40% of our homes passed. We continue to successfully win back customers from competitors, offsetting some of the economy-related losses.
Average revenue per sub in the quarter was $149.04, up 5.7% from the prior-year third quarter and essentially flat sequentially down from $149.12. Our all-digital strategy is progressing according to plan. New York City and Connecticut are complete, and we're currently transitioning our Long Island customer base. We expect to have substantially all of our Cablevision customers transition to a  full digital offering by the end of 2011.
The cable operation's advertising revenue has now seen four consecutive quarters of double-digit growth when compared with the prior-year period with this quarter's increase of 30%. And while the third quarter advertising revenue typically tracks lower than second quarter, this year, the third quarter was 9% higher than the second quarter.
Political advertising was a factor in the quarter. Nonetheless, underlying advertising business made a remarkable comeback from 2009. With the political impact excluded from the third quarter result, ad revenue would've increased by 21% over the prior period.
Our WiFi network is becoming more and more distributed throughout our communities. Customer adoption and use have surged in the third quarter, with new adopters up 25% over the previous quarter, and over 15 million active sessions generated by our customers, up 45% over the previous quarter. We've now installed Optimum WiFi in over 4,000 Optimum small-business locations, giving customers access to mobile Internet at traditional hotspot locations, such as [indiscernible] coffee shops.
Once again, the operating margin for the Cable business in the quarter was over 41%, reflecting the impact of many of the initiatives we have in place, including improved advertising, small and medium business sales, a disciplined programming and operating cost strategy and the increase in data and voice mix.
Our programming cost efforts were on display with the recent retransmission consent situation, which received much media attention. 
Cable capital spending totaled $182 million for the third quarter and $475 million year-to-date. As a percentage of Cable revenue, year-to-date capital spending was 11.6%. Network DVR and downloadable security caused an increasing capital spending this quarter, but future capital will be lower as a result.
We have a number of new products and services either ready for launch or being actively tested for launch in the near future. The RS-DVR service is being launched this quarter, beginning with New York City. Our plan is to end the purchase of physical DVRs soon after this first launch, fulfilling incremental customer demand with the new RS-DVR service. We will use existing DVR inventory [indiscernible] for the remaining non-RS-DVR areas until we have completed the rollout of RS-DVR throughout our footprint.
Our PC to TV Media Relay service, now branded as Optimum Link, is being launched this month. We will charge $4.95 a month for the ability to instantly relay whatever information customers have on their PC, photos, video, documents and Internet content to their television without additional equipment, using only our existing networks.
We have two new applications which we'll launch in the upcoming weeks. The first is a free interactive multiplayer game service, with multiple games for customers of all ages. The second is IO Photos. This video service simply allows customers to view their Facebook photos on their TV after a one-time login through their digital set-top box. And we're continuing to make progress on advanced digital cable services, which will deliver our cable television service in the home to new ethernet-enabled TVs, iPads, tablets and game players. 
By early next year, our customers will be able to view our Cable Television service offerings in their home using these video display devices with a streamlined user interface for advanced digital navigation.
200,000 customers are using our Web DVR service, and 60,000 have downloaded Apple and Android apps in the last several months to do the same thing. 
All of these applications are improved by our strategy to move the intelligence away from the set-top box and onto the network. In doing so, we've gained the flexibility to offer new, more robust services that can easily be upgraded and enhanced. Our enhanced digital network affords us this capability. In the coming months, our customers will see the latest benefits of this strategy, all of which are consistent with our desire to provide the best in convenience in majority [ph].
At Optimum Lightpath, our large business service, revenue from the sale of high-speed ethernet voice and other telecommunication services to mid-sized and larger businesses continued to be strong, increasing 12% over the prior-year period.
AOCF grew by 19% versus the prior period, yielding an operating margin of 39% during the quarter. Margins are improving because incremental revenue is coming in from ethernet revenue and not traditional [ph] company.
I'd now like to turn the call over to Josh Sapan who will discuss Rainbow's results.

componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. In the third quarter, AMC, WE tv and IFC had revenue of $228 million, reflecting an increase of 11% over the third quarter of 2009, and AOCF was $100 million, an increase of 4% compared to the same prior-year period. The increase in revenu
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. In the third quarter, AMC, WE tv and IFC had revenue of $228 million, reflecting an increase of 11% over the third quarter of 2009, and AOCF was $100 million, an increase of 4% compared to the same prior-year period. The increase in revenue included a 13% increase in ad revenue, which was principally due to higher pricing at AMC and WE tv. Affiliate revenue also increased over the prior-year period, which was largely attributable to higher affiliate rates and an increase in subscribers.
The 4% AOCF increase was as expected, with the higher revenue partially offset by higher programming and marketing costs resulting from the introduction of new programming at all three networks, and related marketing and promotion costs for each.
Year-to-date, AMC, WE tv and IFC had revenue of $663 million, an increase of 11% compared to the same period last year, and AOCF of $303 million, an increase of 9% compared to the same period last year.
WE tv's original program, My Fair Wedding and Raising Sextuplets, improved their audience delivery versus the same period last year. Year-to-date, primetime and total day audience delivery were up versus last year. WE tv's newest original series called Downsized premieres this coming Saturday.
AMC's original series, such as Mad Men and Rubicon, continue to deliver strong ratings. The recently completed fourth season of Mad Men was the channel's highest-rated ever approved in original series, with ratings increasing 26% versus last year. This quarter, AMC's primetime household ratings are up 18% versus last year.
Notably, AMC's original series, called The Walking Dead, which premiered last Sunday, had exceptional ratings, delivering 5.2 million total viewers among the targeted 18 to 49 demographic. It was the highest-rated series premiere among all cable channels this year.
Turning now to Rainbow's other programming businesses, which primarily includes Sundance Channel, News 12 and IFC Entertainment, which is our film company. For that group, overall, third quarter net revenue increased by 14% to $68 million, while the AOCF deficit decreased from $10 million to $3 million. The revenue variance was principally driven by increases at Sundance Channel, IFC Entertainment and News 12 Networks. The AOCF variance was principally affected by the improved results of Sundance Channel and News 12 Networks and lower litigation costs. 
I'll now turn the call over to Gregg Siebert, who will cover the company's overall financial position.

componenttextpreview: Thank you, Josh. Let me start by reviewing the leverage at our various borrowing entities. At the end of the third quarter, our total net debt was $10.7 billion, with a consolidated cash position of $428 million. As of September 30, the CSC Holdings restr
componenttext:
Thank you, Josh. Let me start by reviewing the leverage at our various borrowing entities. At the end of the third quarter, our total net debt was $10.7 billion, with a consolidated cash position of $428 million. As of September 30, the CSC Holdings restricted group leverage ratio was 3.4x, and the company's consolidated leverage ratio was 4.1x. As I'll discuss in a few minutes, we expect to close the Bresnan transaction during the fourth quarter.
We intend to fund our equity contribution of approximately $400 million from CSC Holdings, and as a result of this, and the consolidation of the more highly leveraged Bresnan acquisition, total leverage will increase but within a reasonable range. 
Currently, Rainbow National Services has $1.2 billion of debt and $490 million available on its revolving credit facility. The ratio under its bond leverage test as of September 30 was 2.7x.
As Jim mentioned, free cash flow in the third quarter was $225 million, which, for the quarter, was an increase of 9% over the prior-year period. The largest components of free cash flow are AOCF, interest expense, changes in working capital and capital spending.
As Tom pointed out, in the third quarter, capital spending was higher than recent quarters, as our cable company increased its expenditures for its core operations. Investments such as this will help to reduce our overall future capital costs.
For the nine months ended September 30, free cash flow was $656 million.
Now let me provide a brief update on the Bresnan transaction. We've received all of the required approvals from the various regulatory entities, and expect a subsidiary of Cablevision to complete the acquisition of the Bresnan assets by year-end. We're in the process of finalizing the financing transactions, which are anticipated to consist of a $75 million revolving credit facility, $765 million of term loan debt and $250 million of senior unsecured notes. 
As we've previously highlighted, this step will be nonrecourse to Cablevision. We look forward to adding Bresnan Communications to the Cablevision portfolio and continue to be very excited about their potential.
We were active in the quarter in repurchasing our stock. In the three-month period, we bought back 5 million shares at an average price of $26.10, totaling approximately $130 million. Year-to-date, we've repurchased 6.1 million shares, and have spent $157 million on the program to date.
This repurchase activity, combined with the three dividends paid in 2010, represents the return of $260 million, or 40% of year-to-date free cash flow, to shareholders during the first nine months of this year. We intend to continue our share repurchase program during the coming quarters.
Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

componenttext: Well, the network DVR is more efficient economically than the distributed DVR for a variety of reasons. It's cheaper as a stand-alone product on a per set-top box basis, particularly in a whole house environment, which is what where we're going to be offering the network DVR as a product in. So we expect that each incremental DVR unit we add over time and make functional a house will cost less than it would if we were going down the path of physical DVRs. We also think that it's a more marketable product, with less difficulty in selling it due to the fact that you don't have to do truck trips. And so the installation is a software download. So in the long run, it is much more efficient than what we've been historically doing. In order to launch it though, you have to buy a certain amount of storage capacity centrally and server capacity, so that you can go to market. And that's what we've done in the third quarter. As time passes, the actual capital will fall. The other thing that's favorable toward our long-term capital is downloadable security. We have been on a process, for the last several years, to build a new kind of set-top box that doesn't have Cable cards in it. It has a downloadable security system. And these boxes are a lot less expensive than the traditional boxes we've been buying. That, combined with the fact that we are almost 100% digitally penetrated, means that our CPE should fall dramatically in the years to come.

As Tom's highlighted today, we're continuing to reinvest in the business in ways that are going to make us more efficient and, ultimately, on a longer-term basis, a stronger cash flow generator than we are today. So that's obviously priority one going forward. Second, we clearly have intentions of continuing our repurchase program. And that's another activity that we feel gives us a very high economic return. But then we have to take a look at a situation like Bresnan. As I think most of the people on this call are aware, Bresnan had some very unique attributes, from a PAX perspective, from our ability to be able to leverage the asset, and also from an operational perspective, given the high satellite penetration within the Bresnan markets that lead us to believe that we'll be able to produce a higher rate of return out of an investment in Bresnan or in other investment like a Bresnan than we will be able to through the share repurchase program. So there's definitely a tiering effect. Invest in the business, repurchase stock and pay dividends and make acquisitions when they're economically and operationally sensible for the company, and keep that acquisition activity within areas that we refer to as our core competencies. I'd love to see some more, but we don't see any at this point in time. So we'll just see as other acquisition opportunities develop, but nothing on the horizon.

componenttext: Two interesting questions, really. Time Warner's idea of small packages is a great idea if it could be implemented. componenttext:
Thank you, Pat. And good morning. Cablevision continued to perform well in the third quarter. The company's consolidated revenue increased 5.6% to $1.8 billion, fueled by steady growth in our Cable and Rainbow business. Meanwhile, we reported AOCF growth of 3.6%. However, after eliminating a favorable one-time adjustment that impacted our Cable business in the third quarter of last year, AOCF growth for this quarter would have been 8%.
Our results helped drive free cash flow of $225 million for the quarter, bringing the company's year-to-date total to $656 million. An increase of 10% compared to the prior-year period.
We are pleased with our ongoing ability to generate solid results, especially during a quarter that is traditionally seasonally light for our Cable business. The company also continued to experience positive momentum in the advertising market.
Cable and Rainbow delivered strong growth in the first and second quarter of this year. This trend repeated in the third quarter, and both businesses reported impressive double-digit increases in advertising revenue compared with the prior-year period. Cablevision also continued to execute on its plan to return value to shareholders with an active quarter in our stock repurchase program. In addition, the Board of Directors has once again approved a $0.125 per share dividend payable in December.
I would now like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Rutledge.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. And good morning. In the third quarter the Telecom business delivered solid results with revenue growth of 5.2% and AOCF growth of 7.8% after excluding last year's third quarter regulatory adjustment. The company gained 10,000 new high-spe
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. And good morning. In the third quarter the Telecom business delivered solid results with revenue growth of 5.2% and AOCF growth of 7.8% after excluding last year's third quarter regulatory adjustment. The company gained 10,000 new high-speed data customers and 9,000 new voice customers in the quarter.
Basic Video subs declined by 25,000. Third quarter is always the weakest quarter for Cablevision. And while video did better this year than last year, it is negatively impacted by weakness in the housing sector.
The telco overbuild appears to have ceased from a construction standpoint in our footprint. We've seen very little new build activity the quarter. Presently they have passed a little less than 40% of our homes passed. We continue to successfully win back customers from competitors, offsetting some of the economy-related losses.
Average revenue per sub in the quarter was $149.04, up 5.7% from the prior-year third quarter, and essentially flat sequentially down from $149.12. Our all-digital strategy is progressing according to plan. New York City and Connecticut are complete. And we're currently transitioning our Long Island customer base. We expect to have substantially all of our Cablevision customers transition to a  full digital offering by the end of 2011.
The cable operation's advertising revenue has now seen four consecutive quarters of double-digit growth when compared with the prior-year period, with this quarter's increase of 30%. And while the third quarter advertising revenue typically tracks lower than second quarter, this year the third quarter was 9% higher than the second quarter.
Political advertising was a factor in the quarter. Nonetheless, underlying advertising business made a remarkable comeback from 2009. With the political impact excluded from the third quarter results, ad revenue would've increased by 21% over the prior period.
Our WiFi network is becoming more and more distributed throughout our communities. Customer adoption and use have surged in the third quarter, with new adopters up 25% over the previous quarter, and over 15 million active sessions generated by our customers, up 45% over the previous quarter. We've now installed Optimum WiFi in over 4,000 Optimum small-business locations, giving customers access to mobile Internet at traditional hotspot locations, such as coffee shops.
Once again, the operating margin for the Cable business in the quarter was over 41%, reflecting the impact of many of the initiatives we have in place, including improved advertising, small and medium business sales, a disciplined programming and operating cost strategy and the increase in data and voice mix.
Our programming cost efforts were on display with the recent retransmission consent situation, which received much media attention. 
Cable capital spending totaled $182 million for the third quarter and $475 million year-to-date. As a percentage of Cable revenue, year-to-date capital spending was 11.6%. Network DVR and downloadable security caused an increase in capital spending this quarter, but future capital will be lower as a result.
We have a number of new products and services either ready for launch or being actively tested for launch in the near future. The RS-DVR service is being launched this quarter, beginning with New York City. Our plan is to end the purchase of physical DVRs soon after this first launch, fulfilling incremental customer demand with the new RS-DVR service. We will use existing DVR inventory in the interim for the remaining non-RS-DVR areas until we have completed the rollout of RS-DVR throughout our footprint.
Our PC to TV Media Relay service, now branded as Optimum Link, is being launched this month. We will charge $4.95 a month for the ability to instantly relay whatever information customers have on their PC - photos, video, documents and Internet content - to their television without additional equipment. Using only our existing networks.
We have two new applications which we'll launch in the upcoming weeks. The first is a free interactive multiplayer game service, with multiple games for customers of all ages. The second is IO Photos. This video service simply allows customers to view their Facebook photos on their TV after a one-time login through their digital set-top box. And we're continuing to make progress on advanced digital cable services which will deliver our cable television service in the home to new Ethernet-enabled TVs, iPads, tablets and game players. 
By early next year our customers will be able to view our Cable Television service offerings in their home using these video display devices with a streamlined user interface for advanced digital navigation.
200,000 customers are using our Web DVR service. And 60,000 have downloaded Apple and Android apps in the last several months to do the same thing. 
All of these applications are improved by our strategy to move the intelligence away from the set-top box and onto the network. In doing so we've gained the flexibility to offer new, more robust services that can easily be upgraded and enhanced. Our enhanced digital network affords us this capability. In the coming months our customers will see the latest benefits of this strategy, all of which are consistent with our desire to provide the best in convenience.
At Optimum Lightpath, our large business service, revenue from the sale of high-speed Ethernet voice and other telecommunication services to mid-sized and larger businesses continued to be strong. Increasing 12% over the prior-year period.
AOCF grew by 19% versus the prior period, yielding an operating margin of 39% during the quarter. Margins are improving because incremental revenue is coming in from Ethernet revenue and not the traditional company.
I'd now like to turn the call over to Josh Sapan who will discuss Rainbow's results.

Affiliate revenue also increased over the prior-year period, which was largely attributable to higher affiliate rates and an increase in subscribers.
The 4% AOCF increase was as expected, with the higher revenue partially offset by higher programming and marketing costs resulting from the introduction of new programming at all three networks, and related marketing and promotion costs for each.
Year-to-date, AMC, WE tv and IFC had revenue of $663 million, an increase of 11% compared to the same period last year. And AOCF of $303 million, an increase of 9% compared to the same period last year.
WE tv's original programs, My Fair Wedding and Raising Sextuplets, improved their audience delivery versus the same period last year. Year-to-date, primetime and total day audience delivery were up versus last year. WE tv's newest original series called Downsized premieres this coming Saturday.
AMC's original series, such as Mad Men and Rubicon, continue to deliver strong ratings. The recently completed fourth season of Mad Men was the channel's highest-rated ever for an original series, with ratings increasing 26% versus last year. This quarter, AMC's primetime household ratings are up 18% versus last year.
Notably, AMC's original series called The Walking Dead, which premiered last Sunday, had exceptional ratings, delivering 5.2 million total viewers among the targeted 18 to 49 demographic. It was the highest-rated series premiere among all cable channels this year.
Turning now to Rainbow's other programming businesses, which primarily includes Sundance Channel, News 12 and IFC Entertainment, which is our film company. For that group, overall, third quarter net revenue increased by 14% to $68 million, while the AOCF deficit decreased from $10 million to $3 million. The revenue variance was principally driven by increases at Sundance Channel, IFC Entertainment and News 12 Networks. The AOCF variance was principally affected by the improved results of Sundance Channel and News 12 Networks and lower litigation costs. 
I'll now turn the call over to Gregg Siebert, who will cover the company's overall financial position.

componenttext:
Thank you, Josh. Let me start by reviewing the leverage at our various borrowing entities. At the end of the third quarter our total net debt was $10.7 billion, with a consolidated cash position of $428 million. As of September 30, the CSC Holdings restricted group leverage ratio was 3.4x, and the company's consolidated leverage ratio was 4.1x. As I'll discuss in a few minutes, we expect to close the Bresnan transaction during the fourth quarter.
We intend to fund our equity contribution of approximately $400 million from CSC Holdings, and as a result of this, and the consolidation of the more highly leveraged Bresnan acquisition, total leverage will increase, but within a reasonable range. 
Currently, Rainbow National Services has $1.2 billion of debt and $490 million available on its revolving credit facility. The ratio under its bond leverage test as of September 30 was 2.7x.
As Jim mentioned, free cash flow in the third quarter was $225 million, which for the quarter was an increase of 9% over the prior-year period. The largest components of free cash flow are AOCF, interest expense, changes in working capital and capital spending.
As Tom pointed out, in the third quarter capital spending was higher than recent quarters as our cable company increased its expenditures for its core operations. Investments such as this will help to reduce our overall future capital costs.
For the nine months ended September 30, free cash flow was $656 million.
Now let me provide a brief update on the Bresnan transaction. We've received all of the required approvals from the various regulatory entities, and expect a subsidiary of Cablevision to complete the acquisition of the Bresnan assets by year-end. We're in the process of finalizing the financing transactions, which are anticipated to consist of a $75 million revolving credit facility, $765 million of term loan debt and $250 million of senior unsecured notes. 
As we've previously highlighted, this step will be nonrecourse to Cablevision. We look forward to adding Bresnan Communications to the Cablevision portfolio and continue to be very excited about their potential.
We were active in the quarter in repurchasing our stock. In the three-month period we bought back 5 million shares at an average price of $26.10, totaling approximately $130 million. Year-to-date, we've repurchased 6.1 million shares, and have spent $157 million on the program to date.
This repurchase activity, combined with the three dividends paid in 2010, represents the return of $260 million, or 40% of year-to-date free cash flow, to shareholders during the first nine months of this year. We intend to continue our share repurchase program during the coming quarters.
Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

componenttext: Well, the network DVR is more efficient economically than the distributed DVR for a variety of reasons. It's cheaper as a stand-alone product on a per set-top box basis, particularly in a whole house environment which is what where we're going to be offering the network DVR as a product in. In order to launch it though, you have to buy a certain amount of storage capacity centrally, and server capacity, so that you can go to market. And that's what we've done in the third quarter. As time passes the actual capital will fall. The other thing that's favorable toward our long-term capital is downloadable security. We have been on a process for the last several years to build a new kind of set-top box that doesn't have Cable cards in it. It has a downloadable security system. And we have the rights through our contracts to provide services in the home. Providing mobile services on different platforms is a different rights structure in many agreements. And assimilating those in a coherent way with a viable product is a challenge, but I think it can be done. But it's not a technical issue. It's a rights issue.
